newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Skandia says Q1 non-life, reinsurance profit up.
newsitem.headline: Skandia says Q1 non-life, reinsurance profit up.

text.p: Swedish insurer Skandia managed to buck negative trends in non-life insurance by showing a higher operating profit for non-life and reinsurance when releasing first quarter earnings on Tuesday.

Operating profit for non-life insurance and reinsurance rose to 1.13 billion crowns from 794 million in the year earlier quarter, boosted by the Skandia Norden unit's performance, the company said in a statement.
"The first quarter was characterised by continued fierce competition in the non-life insurance and reinsurance areas," chief executive Lars-Eric Petersson said in the statement.
"Much to our satisfaction, despite this, our technical result improved by 20 percent (to 483 million crowns) on a rolling 12-month basis."
Life and unit linked assurance kept going strong with operating profit rising to 518 million crowns from 318 million, mainly lifted by advances in the U.S. and Sweden.
"Growth in life and unit linked assurance is strong, at the same time as Skandia is entering new markets," Petersson said. "Profitability continues to be very satisfactory throughout this segment."
Total operating profit jumped 61 percent to 1.48 billion crowns and total premiums rose 27 percent to 18.59 billion crowns.
Premiums in non-life insurance and reinsurance slipped to 6.97 billion crowns from 6.99 billion, while premiums in life and unit linked assurance surged to 11.62 billion crowns from 7.69 billion.
"Growth in written (life and unit linked assurance) premium remained strong in the first quarter in the U.S., at 54 percent, and in Sweden, where the increase was 62 percent," the company said.
"During the last 12-month period Skandia's market share in the U.S. variable annuities market has risen from 3.0 percent to 3.8 percent -- a growth rate that is faster than the largest competitors'."
On a rolling 12-month basis, earnings per share rose to 14 crowns from 11 and net asset value per share increased to 181 crowns from 174.
Assets under management increased by 15 percent to 169 billion crowns in the first quarter.
Skandia's return on investments was lifted by higher share prices with the yield on the equity portfolio rising to 9.1 percent from 8.0 percent.
The total yield on investments, calculated at current value, increased to 2.9 percent from 2.5 percent and investment assets rose by three billion crowns to 50.9 billion.
"Investment income during the quarter was high and despite unease in the stock markets around the world, a continued positive trend was noted through April," Petersson said.
"Work on discontinuing the direct insurance activities in the U.S. and the restructuring of the Italian operations are proceeding according to plan," he added.
